TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ServiceInstallerDialog extends System.Windows.Forms.Form

Docs.summary: Provides a dialog box, which prompts for account information of a Windows Service application.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Normally, you do not use the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> class directly within your code; this dialog is generally used by the installation utility for a Windows Service application.
If a <xref:System.ServiceProcess.ServiceProcessInstaller> object has the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.ServiceProcessInstaller.Account%2A> set to `User`, and either the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.ServiceProcessInstaller.Username%2A> or <xref:System.ServiceProcess.ServiceProcessInstaller.Password%2A> is an empty string (""), then the installation utility uses <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> to prompt for these values.
<xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> derives from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>; use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> class methods and properties to display and manipulate the dialog. For example, use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.ShowDialog%2A> to display the form, and then check the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Result%2A> before validating the input text for the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Username%2A> and <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Password%2A> properties.
> [!NOTE] > <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> does not check the credentials and privileges for the specified account. For example, the user might enter an invalid account name and password for the computer, or the account might not have the correct privileges to run as a service. Validate the user input to ensure that the installed service runs successfully.
## Examples The following example uses a <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> to prompt the user for a service installation account.
[!code-cpp[ServiceInstallConfig#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_CLR/ServiceInstallConfig/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[ServiceInstallConfig#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_CLR/ServiceInstallConfig/CS/source.cs#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the service account form.

remarks.format: ## Remarks A new <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> form has its <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Result%2A> set to <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialogResult.OK>, the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Username%2A> set to an empty string (""), and the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Password%2A> set to an empty string.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig void Main() cil managed

Docs.summary: Begins running a standard application message loop and displays the service account form.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is equivalent to calling <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Application.Run%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> on a new <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> form; it is typically used for testing purposes.
Call <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.ShowDialog%2A> on the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> form to display the dialog box in your application.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Password { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.Password : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the password for the service account form.
Docs.value: A string representing the password in the service account form. The default is an empty string ("").

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> does not validate the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Username%2A> and <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Password%2A> values. The dialog checks that the user confirms the password, but it does not authenticate the account credentials on the computer.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Result As ServiceInstallerDialogResult

Docs.summary: Gets the dialog result for the service account form.
Docs.value: A indicating the user response to the dialog box. The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.ShowDialog%2A> to prompt the user for the service installation account, then check the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Result%2A> value. If the value is <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialogResult.OK>, verify that the input <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Username%2A> and <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Password%2A> are valid.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Username { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.Username : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the user name for the service account form.
Docs.value: A string representing the user name in the service account form. The default is an empty string ("").

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog> does not validate the <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Username%2A> or <xref:System.ServiceProcess.Design.ServiceInstallerDialog.Password%2A> values.
